info.title: Understanding Scale in Architecture
info.subtitle: The essential concept that connects real-world structures to their representations
info.scaleInfo: Scale is a crucial concept in architecture that allows designers to represent large structures on paper or in small models. It defines the relationship between the dimensions on a drawing or model and the actual size of the built structure.
info.whyScaleInfo1: Enables representation of buildings at a manageable size
info.whyScaleInfo2: Ensures proportional accuracy across all elements
info.whyScaleInfo3: Facilitates communication between architects, engineers, and clients
info.whyScaleInfo4: Allows for precise measurements and dimensions
info.workingWithScaleInfo: When working with scale, you need to consistently convert between real-world measurements and their scaled representations. A scale of 1: 50 means 1 unit on your drawing (e.g., 1 cm) represents 50 units in reality (50 cm).
info.tips1: Always note the scale on your drawings
info.tips2: Choose an appropriate scale for the level of detail needed
info.tips3: Use a scale ruler for accurate measurements on physical drawings
info.tips5: Practice converting between real measurements and scaled dimensions
info.tips6: Be consistent with your chosen units (metric or imperial) throughout a project
